THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP BIO-INSPIRED POLYTETRAFLUOROETHYLENE (PTFE)-BASED SOLID LUBRICANT COATINGS FOR 60NITI (NITINOL 60) MATERIAL. NITINOL 60 IS CURRENTLY UNDER EXTENSIVE EVALUATION AT NASA DUE TO ITS UNIQUE COMBINATIONS OF PHYSICAL PROPERTIES THAT MAKE IT VERY DESIRABLE FOR NASA S SPACE MECHANISMS AND AEROSPACE APPLICATIONS. HOWEVER  IT HAS POOR FRICTION AND WEAR PERFORMANCES IN DRY CONTACT CONDITIONS. THE PROPOSED NOVEL COATINGS CONSIST OF A BIO-INSPIRED POLYDOPAMINE (PDA) ADHESIVE UNDER-LAYER AND A PTFE OR A MIXED PTFE AND GRAPHITE SOLID LUBRICANT TOP-LAYER. THE COATINGS ARE EXPECTED TO REDUCE THE FRICTION OF THE NITINOL 60 MATERIAL BY OVER 85% AND ITS WEAR RATE BY 50% DURING DRY CONTACT CONDITIONS TO MEET A RANGE OF NASA S CRITICAL APPLICATION NEEDS. SPECIFICALLY  THE NOVEL COATINGS WILL ENABLE NITINOL 60 BALL BEARINGS AND TIMING GEARS TO BE DEVELOPED FOR USE IN THE WATER RECOVERY SYSTEM OF THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION (ISS) TO COMBAT CURRENT ISSUES WITH THESE TRIBOLOGICAL COMPONENTS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL BE PERFORMED COLLABORATIVELY BY THREE INVESTIGATORS FROM THREE DIFFERENT DISCIPLINES IN TWO ARKANSAS UNIVERSITIES. THE PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE COATING PROCESS DEVELOPMENT  COMPUTATIONAL AND ANALYTICAL MODELING  AND PERFORMANCE EVALUATION TO ADDRESS NASA S CRITICAL NEEDS IN SOLID LUBRICATION OF NITINOL 60. THE RESEARCH WILL BE CLOSELY GUIDED BY NASA SENIOR SCIENTISTS DRS. CHRISTOPHER DELLACORTE AND SAMUEL A. HOWARD FROM THE NASA GLENN RESEARCH CENTER (GRC) AND INTEGRATE WITH THEIR RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS TO ENSURE ITS DIRECT BENEFIT TO NASA. THE PROJECT GOAL WILL BE ATTAINED BY ACCOMPLISHING THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC RESEARCH OBJECTIVES: 1) DEVELOP PROCESSES TO FABRICATE BIO-INSPIRED PTFE-BASED SOLID LUBRICANT COATINGS ON NITINOL 60 SUBSTRATES (ZOU)  2) EXPERIMENTALLY EVALUATE THE MECHANICAL AND TRIBOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF THE COATED NITINOL 60 (ZOU)  3) GAIN A FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE ADHESION MECHANISMS OF PDA/PTFE COATING ON NITINOL 60 THROUGH MULTI-SCALE MODELING  WHICH WILL PROVIDE FEEDBACK FOR EXPERIMENTAL REFINEMENT OF THE SOLID LUBRICANT COATINGS (WANG)  AND 4) DEVELOP ANALYTICAL MODELS TO PREDICT STATIC AND DYNAMIC PERFORMANCES OF THE COATED NITNINOL 60 BEARINGS (MILLER). THE PROPOSED COATING TECHNOLOGIES ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THE HUMAN EXPLORATION&OPERATIONS MISSION DIRECTORATE (HEOMD) FOR IMPROVING THE WASTE WATER PROCESSING BEARINGS AND GEARS IN THE ISS  THE NEEDS OF THE SPACE TECHNOLOGY MISSION DIRECTORATE (STMD) FOR RESILIENT MECHANICAL SYSTEMS IN LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEMS FOR LONG TERM EXPLORATION  AND THE NEEDS OF THE AERONAUTICS RESEARCH MISSION DIRECTORATE (ARMD) FOR LIGHTWEIGHT AIRCRAFT COMPONENTS. THE SUCCESSFULLY DEVELOPED COATINGS CAN BE APPLIED TO SHOCKPROOF AND CORROSION PROOF BEARINGS FOR SPACESUITS; LIFE SUPPORT MACHINERY; GUIDANCE  NAVIGATION  AND CONTROL MECHANISMS; AND OTHER MECHANISMS THAT REQUIRE SOLID LUBRICATION. THE PROJECT PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES TO BUILD PARTNERSHIPS AMONG ARKANSAS UNIVERSITIES  NASA GRC  AND ARKANSAS INDUSTRIES. IT WILL STRENGTHEN ARKANSAS S RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE AND SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY CAPABILITIES IN ADVANCED MATERIALS  WHICH IS ONE OF THE SIX ECONOMIC CLUSTERS IN ARKANSAS. DUE TO THE VERSATILITY OF THE PROPOSED COATING SYSTEM  THE FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING GAINED FROM THIS RESEARCH AND THE COATING TECHNOLOGIES DEVELOPED CAN BE APPLIED TO IMPROVE THE DURABILITY OF SURFACES OF VARIOUS MECHANICAL COMPONENTS USED IN ARKANSAS MANUFACTURING  AEROSPACE  DEFENSE  AGRICULTURE  AND GAS AND OIL INDUSTRIES. WE ALSO PLAN TO COMMERCIALIZE THE TECHNOLOGIES DEVELOPED BY PARTNERING WITH NASA AND ARKANSAS-BASED COMPANIES. THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE CREATION OF NEW PRODUCTS AND NEW HIGH-PAYING JOBS  WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AND BOLSTER THE KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY IN ARKANSAS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT THIS PROPOSAL SUPPORTS THE PH.D. RESEARCH OF ANTHONY GARGANO. IT INTEGRATES THE EXPERTISE OF JUSTIN SIMON AT THE JOHNSON SPACE CENTER (JSC) WITH THAT OF PH.D. ADVISOR ZACHARY SHARP AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO. THE RESEARCH PLAN CREATES A FAR BROADER RESEARCH EXPERIENCE THAN WOULD BE POSSIBLE WITHOUT THE JSC CONNECTION. MR. GARGANO WILL STUDY THE CHLORINE AND HYDROGEN ISOTOPE GEOCHEMISTRY OF PRIMITIVE CHONDRITES IN ORDER TO BETTER ASCERTAIN THE SOURCES OF VOLATILES INCORPORATED IN THESE BODIES  AND ULTIMATELY IN THE TERRESTRIAL PLANETS. THE PROPOSED COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE CENTER FOR STABLE ISOTOPES  UNM AND JSC WILL GREATLY AUGMENT THE RESEARCH EXPERIENCE OF MR. GARGANO BY INCLUDING THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE AT JSC WITH THOSE AT CSI. DR. SIMON HAS SPENT THE LAST SIX YEARS WORKING WITH SUMMER INTERNS ON THE PETROGRAPHY AND TEXTURES OF PRIMITIVE METEORITES AND WILL WORK WITH MR. GARGANO OVER THE THREE SUMMERS OF HIS RESEARCH AT JSC ON THIS CRITICAL COMPLIMENT TO THE H AND CL ISOTOPE GEOCHEMISTRY  WHICH WILL BE MADE AT UNM. MR. GARGANO WILL ALSO BE GIVEN THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH THE ANTARCTIC METEORITE COLLECTION  FINDING APPROPRIATE SAMPLES FOR HIS RESEARCH AND GAINING A FULLER KNOWLEDGE OF THE TYPES OF METEORITES THAT EXIST. FINALLY  HE WILL WORK WITH DR. SIMON AND DR. SCOTT MESSENGER USING THE NANOSIMS IN ORDER TO MAKE HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTION H AND CL ISOTOPE MEASUREMENTS OF SUBDOMAINS IN SELECTED SAMPLES. THE ION MICROPROBE WORK WILL ALLOW FOR MR. GARGANO TO DISENTANGLE THE ISOTOPE SIGNATURES OF DISTINCT PHASES FROM THE BULK ROCK SAMPLES. MR. GARGANO S ULTIMATE OBJECTIVE IS TO BECOME PART OF THE NEXT GENERATION OF PLANETARY SCIENTISTS  AND THE ADDITION OF THE NASA PORTION OF HIS RESEARCH WILL MAKE HIS PH.D. A FAR RICHER EXPERIENCE THAN IF HE WERE TO WORK ONLY AT UNM. OUR HYPOTHESIS IS THAT THERE ARE DISTINCT H AND CL RESERVOIRS THAT HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE VOLATILE CONTENTS OF CHONDRITES. NEBULAR HYDROGEN SHOULD HAVE AN EXTREMELY LOW D/H RATIO. WATER ICE SHOULD HAVE A HIGHER D/H RATIO AND ORGANIC HYDROGEN SHOULD HAVE AN EXTREMELY HIGH D/H RATIO. OXIDATION OF ORGANIC MATERIAL AND/OR REDUCTION OF H2O SHOULD RESULT IN A WATER COMPONENT WITH A HIGH D/H RATIO  BUT LOWER THAN THE EXTRAORDINARILY HIGH D/H RATIO OF ORGANIC MATTER. THE SOLAR NEBULA CL ISOTOPE COMPOSITION IS LIGHT  AND IS PRESERVED IN SOME METEORITES AND PRIMITIVE MARTIAN METEORITES  WHILE CL FROM HCL-HYDRATES IS HEAVY. COMBINING THE TWO ISOTOPE SYSTEMS WILL ALLOW US TO BETTER CONSTRAIN THE VOLATILE SOURCES OF CHONDRITES. MR. GARGANO S ULTIMATE PROFESSIONAL GOAL IS TO BE PART OF THE NEXT GENERATION OF PLANETARY SCIENTISTS. THIS FITS INTO THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL OPPORTUNITY  THE NASA EDUCATION AERONAUTICS SCHOLARSHIP AND ADVANCED STEM TRAINING AND RESEARCH (AS&ASTAR) FELLOWSHIP ACTIVITY. AS STATED IN THE PROPOSAL ANNOUNCEMENT  THIS GRANT WILL STRENGTHEN  INVOLVEMENT WITH HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS TO ENSURE THAT NASA CAN MEET FUTURE WORKFORCE NEEDS IN STEM FIELDS.  THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL BRING TOGETHER THE EXPERTISE OF THE CENTER FOR STABLE ISOTOPES (CSI) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO WITH THAT OF JSC. THE CSI HAS DEVELOPED THE UNIQUE CAPABILITY TO MEASURE ULTRA-SMALL QUANTITIES OF CL AND H IN BULK SAMPLES. JSC HAS A LONG HISTORY OF EXCELLENCE IN UNDERSTANDING THE PETROGRAPHY AND MINERALOGY OF METEORITE SAMPLES AND HAS A NANOSIMS THAT IS TAILORED TO METEORITE STUDIES. MR. GARGANO S RESEARCH PROPOSAL WILL INTRODUCE HIM TO THE PHILOSOPHY AND RESEARCH TEAM AT JSC AND GIVE HIM HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE WITH THE ANTARCTIC METEORITE COLLECTION  ARGUABLY THE FINEST COLLECTION OF FRESH METEORITES IN THE WORLD. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL GREATLY FACILITATE MR. GARGANO S GOAL OF BECOMING A SKILLED PLANETARY SCIENTIST.

THE DISTRIBUTION OF OXIDATION CONDITIONS IN THE SOLAR NEBULA IS NOT WELL-CONSTRAINED. ASTEROIDS RECORD THESE CONDITIONS IN THEIR MINERALOGIES  BUT SENDING SAMPLING MISSIONS TO EACH REPRESENTATIVE ASTEROID IS IMPRACTICAL. METEORITES SAMPLED FROM THESE BODIES RECORD NEBULAR CONDITIONS  BUT ALONE DO NOT HAVE GEOLOGIC CONTEXT. IF OXIDATION CONDITIONS CAN BE DETERMINED REMOTELY  THEN FURTHER CONSTRAINTS COULD BE PROVIDED FOR NEBULAR CONDITIONS AND SUBSEQUENT MIXING OF PLANETARY MATERIAL. WE PROPOSE A COORDINATED PETROLOGIC-SPECTRAL STUDY OF METEORITES THAT EXAMINES OXIDATION CONDITIONS AND THE CORRESPONDING EFFECTS ON SPECTRAL SIGNATURES. THIS STUDY CONSISTS OF THREE PHASES: (1) THE PETROLOGIC ANALYSIS AND THERMODYNAMIC CALCULATION OF OXIDATION CONDITIONS PRESERVED IN MINERAL ASSEMBLAGES AMONG METEORITES SOURCED FROM ASTEROIDS THAT HAVE PARTIALLY MELTED AND RECRYSTALLIZED (ACHONDRITES): ACAPULCOITES  ANGRITES  AUBRITES  BRACHINITES  LODRANITES  WINONAITES  AND UNGROUPED ACHONDRITES; (2) DETERMINATION OF OXIDATION-SPECIFIC SPECTRAL FEATURES AMONG THESE METEORITE GROUPS USING THE MODIFIED GAUSSIAN MODEL; AND (3) IDENTIFICATION OF MAIN-BELT ASTEROIDS WITH OXIDATION-SPECIFIC SPECTRAL FEATURES USING EXISTING TELESCOPIC DATA. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL MAP ASTEROID OXIDATION CONDITIONS  FACILITATE THE ASSOCIATION OF METEORITES WITH POTENTIAL PARENT BODIES  AND PROVIDE COMPOSITIONAL DATA FOR ASTEROIDS THAT WILL FACILITATE FUTURE SOLAR SYSTEM EXPLORATION  BOTH HUMAN AND ROBOTIC.

THE MOLECULAR STRUCTURE OF H2O-ICE IS DEPENDENT ON ITS FORMATION CONDITIONS  SUCH AS TEMPERATURE AND PRESSURE  AND CAN THEREFORE PROVIDE A DIRECT INDICATION FOR PHYSICAL PROCESSES  SUCH AS METEORITE IMPACTS  IRRADIATION  AND CRYOVOLCANISM  THAT HAVE IMPACTED THAT ICE S EMPLACEMENT AND INFLUENCED THE EVOLUTION OF THE ICY SURFACE ON WHICH IT RESIDES. THE ANALYSIS OF SPACECRAFT OBSERVATIONS OF MULTIPLE SOLAR SYSTEM OBJECTS  OBTAINED FROM THE PLANETARY DATA SYSTEM ARCHIVES  WILL ALLOW FOR A COMPARATIVE STUDY OF AMORPHOUS AND CRYSTALLINE H2O-ICE IN VASTLY DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTS AS A WAY OF UNDERSTANDING THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES THAT OCCUR ON THE SURFACES OF THESE OBJECTS. I WILL WORK WITH DR. MURTHY GUDIPATI AT NASA JPL TO IMPOSE LOW-TEMPERATURE  RADIATION-INDUCED CONDITIONS ON H2OICE IN ORDER TO COMPARE LABORATORY AND SPACECRAFT SPECTRA TO CONSTRAIN THE PROPERTIES OF THE H2O-ICE ON ICY BODIES. ADDITIONALLY  I WILL PERFORM GROUND-BASED OBSERVATIONS OF SEVERAL ICY SOLAR SYSTEM OBJECTS AS A PROOF-OF-CONCEPT IN ORDER TO PROVIDE FOLLOW-UP SUPPORT. BY COMPARING NEAR-INFRARED SPECTROSCOPIC SPACECRAFT  LABORATORY  AND GROUND-BASED OBSERVATIONS OF H2O-ICE  I INTEND TO CONSTRAIN THE EVOLUTIONARY HISTORY AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF THESE OBJECTS BY LINKING THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCES AND SPATIAL VARIATIONS OF AMORPHOUS AND CRYSTALLINE H2O-ICE TO THE AFOREMENTIONED PHYSICAL PROCESSES AT PLAY.

COMETS ARE ~4.6 BILLION YEAR OLD SURVIVING RELICS OF THE SUN S PROTOPLANETARY DISK AND  IN ADDITION TO WATER  CONTAIN INVENTORIES RICH IN CO AND CO2 GASES. THESE GASES ARE DIFFICULT  IF NOT IMPOSSIBLE  TO STUDY THROUGH THE EARTH S CO2-RICH ATMOSPHERE VIA A PROPER OPTICAL WINDOW. IN THIS WORK  WE PROPOSE TO PERFORM ONE OF THE LARGEST STUDIES EVER PERFORMED OF COMETS IN THE INFRARED WAVELENGTHS USING DATA OBTAINED FROM NASA S NEOWISE REACTIVATION MISSION WITH ITS 3.4 AND 4.6 MICRON BANDPASS CHANNELS (W1 AND W2  RESPECTIVELY). GASEOUS CO AND CO2 HAVE STRONG BANDS AT PEAK WAVELENGTHS 4.67 AND 4.23 MICRONS  RESPECTIVELY  BOTH FALLING WITHIN W2. ON THE OTHER HAND  COMETARY DUST CONTINUUM DOMINATES IN W1. WE WILL OBTAIN COMETARY PHOTOMETRY USING THE METHODS DESCRIBED IN BAUER ET AL. (2015) TO CONSTRAIN PROPERTIES OF THE DUST AND NUCLEI OF ~100 NEOWISE OBSERVED COMETS  AND TO STUDY THEIR CO/CO2 EMISSION. SCIENTIFIC INTEREST LIES IN A BETTER DETERMINATION OF THE ABUNDANCE OF THESE VOLATILES  IN COMPARING AND CONTRASTING THE NUCLEUS  DUST AND GAS PROPERTIES OF SHORT AND LONG PERIOD COMET POPULATIONS AND IN WHAT THIS MAY ULTIMATELY IMPLY FOR THE FORMATION OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEXT-GENERATION BATTERIES THAT MAXIMIZE ENERGY DENSITY WHILE MEETING THE SAFETY AND POWER REQUIREMENTS OF ELECTRIC AIRCRAFT AND ON-BOARD POWERED DEVICE APPLICATIONS IS CRUCIAL FOR CONTINUED NASA MISSION SUCCESS. TO MEET THESE DEMANDS  SIGNIFICANT RESEARCH IS UNDERWAY TO ENABLE BATTERIES USING A SOLID LITHIUM METAL (LIM) ANODE  WHICH IS CONSIDERED THE  HOLY GRAIL  OF ANODE MATERIALS DUE TO ITS LOWEST ELECTROCHEMICAL POTENTIAL AND HIGHEST ENERGY DENSITY. STILL AN IMMATURE TECHNOLOGY  THE LITHIUM ANODE IS NOT WITHOUT ITS CHALLENGES. TO ADDRESS THE MAJOR ISSUE OF LI DENDRITE FORMATION  WE PROPOSE A THIN HOLEY 2D NANOSHEETS (H2D) COATING ON LIM BATTERY SEPARATORS. WITH NANOSCALE THROUGH-SHEET HOLES AND HIGH THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY  H2D IS EXPECTED TO PROVIDE EXCELLENT BLOCKING OF DENDRITE GROWTH BY REDUCING THE SURFACE AREA TO VOLUME RATIO OF DEPOSITED LI WHILE MAINTAINING FAST LI ION DIFFUSION KINETICS. A FULL INVESTIGATION OF FACILE  SCALABLE H2D SYNTHESIS TECHNIQUES; BATTERY SEPARATOR LAYER FABRICATION AND MATERIALS  THERMAL  AND DIFFUSION KINETICS CHARACTERIZATION; AND ELECTROCHEMICAL PERFORMANCE OF SYMMETRIC LI AND FULL LIS ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS CONTAINING THE COATED MEMBRANE IS PROPOSED. WITH PRELIMINARY DATA AS REFERENCE  THE H2D COATING SHOULD ENABLE STABLE LIM CYCLING AT COMPETITIVE CURRENT DENSITIES OF 3 MA/CM2 AND GREATER.

WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT DNA HUMAN FIBROBLASTS ARE LESS SENSITIVE TO RADIATION AND THEREFORE THEY WILL SHOW LOWER AMOUNT OF DAMAGES COMPARED TO HUMAN EPITHELIAL CELLS AND THIS WILL BE DEPENDED ON RADIATION TYPE  DOSE AND/OR EXPOSURE TIME. TO TEST THIS HYPOTHESIS  DIFFERENT GI MARKERS AND WHOLE TRANSCRIPTOME WILL BE ASSESSED.
